@Jake in DC: you read the site, but you misunderstood it. I've had to be on unemployment in Ohio; so has my husband. We know precisely how it works.

The MAXIMUM you can collect on is $41,600. That means if you earn $100,000, you only get 50% of $41,600. That's the top salary for UI. (I am sure it's more in the expensive states like NY and CA; Ohio is a pretty poor state. It's much LESS in Florida, where I have also been unemployed.)

No matter what you earn, it is 50% of what you earned in the past calendar year (up to $22,300, which is 1/2 of the maximum).

To earn this, you must have worked for the past 6-7 months, and earned a minimum weekly salary (I think $150 a week). So you can't get unemployment just for losing your babysitting gig. it also has to be income "on the books".

You can get UI for working as little as 20 weeks in a year, but your UI check then only runs for 20 weeks (not 26).

You misunderstand the "20 week rule"; it means "the previous 12 months" and not "inside this calendar year". So if it's January, your work the previous year counts towards your benefit.

You also misunderstand that the check is only reduced by work you do DURING the period you collect UI checks (not before or after); you CAN work (say, part-time doing temp work) but then your UI check is reduced.

It does NOT mean that you can't work 5 months of the year, and then collect for 7 months, because presumably you worked all of the previous year. Most states calculate UI this way.

Our health insurance company changed the rules on blood tests WITHOUT INFORMING us and so when we got a $90 bill from the testing company we assume it would, as it had been for 15 years, paid. Then, while we were away on  a trip we started getting calls on our voice mail that sounded suspiciously like junk calls -- the callers said something like "we want to help you do something that will keep you from harming your credit history -- without telling us who they were. Needless to say when we found out who they were (some outfit out in Indiana I believe) I called our insurance company and raised hell. They assured me that this time around it was their error and they would fix the problem. They didn't and we ended up paying. God knows what this has done to a perfect credit rating but it is just wrong. Unethical, unprofessional and stupid.

When my son, now 17, was 2, he tripped and fell while we were on a trip to Washington, DC. He needed stitches and our insurance covered this. I paid the copay. We went home and I forgot all about it.

6 months later, I got a notice in the mail that we still hadn't paid. I called our insurance company, but they had indeed paid; I called the hospital and directed them to our insurance, and was assured it would be taken care of. 6 months later, same thing, only this time it had been referred to a collection agency. 6 months later, same thing. After about 2-3 years of this - each time they would assure me it was all settled - I just paid the amount I didn't owe, about $375. In other words, extortion.

Plus, my credit score had gone down by over 100 points.

But that wasn't the end. It STILL follows me, 15 years later. No matter how good my actual credit is, the idiotic 'error' -I do have to wonder if it really was an error, as this 'forgetfulness' would be very profitable to the hospital, as they were in fact paid twice - the 'error' still follows my credit. It just doesn't go away.

No one cares--hospitals get their money, insurance companies get theirs, collection agencies get theirs, and credit agencies have a reason for existence. The only losers in the system are the American consumer, one person at a time. This is a HUGE drain on our economy, but it's done in tiny little bits no one cares to see. Sooner or later, the organism dies.

The credit system in the U.S. needs an overhaul, too. It's an unregulated, uncontrolled, and unfairly operated industry. It's unfair to credit users—individuals and families—who, without their permission, give merchants, corporations, health insurers, and others who sell products and services to "consumers" way too much power and say about who gets credit and how much that credit costs.
With mortgage, federal and prime interest rates at all-time lows, credit card companies get away with charging exorbitant and obscene interest on consumer loans and credit card purchases.
The federal Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) should get involved in these issues, and exercise the powers it's been given to speak up for American families and individuals . Any entity issuing credit to families and individuals in America should be monitored, regulated, and controlled. Right now they are not. That must end.
